Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Tarek M. Elgindi is "Local and Nonlocal Effects in Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Peter Constantin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dynamics of incompressible fluids, while an old and active subject, is still very elusive due to the possibility of rapid small-scale creation as well as the inherent non-locality of incompressible fluid motion. 

During this project, the PI endeavoured to give a more accurate description of fluid motion in certain "critical settings." Specifically, we focused on understanding the interplay between "locality" and "non-locality"  in fluids--local effects being those which only affect the dynamics of a fluid in local regions while non-local effects influence the whole of the fluid at once. The PI showed that non-local effects can lead to rapid small scale creation in certain settings. The PI gave criteria for the convergence of solutions to the Navier Stokes equations to those of the Euler equations as kinematic viscosity is sent to zero. The PI worked also on the long-time behavior of stratified fluids and on the effects of rotation on stabilizing two dimensional and three dimensional fluids.  

The PI also showed that local mildly singular structures are propagated in zero-viscosity fluids. The PI then moved to show that the non-locality in fluids can be locally reduced by imposing a high degree of symmetry on the solutions. This then led to advances in our understanding of singularity formation and long-time behavior of ideal fluids through the introduction of the scale-invariant solutions.
